title: 108_hr1617
content: The "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" establishes a program to provide grants for projects addressing railroad infrastructure deficiencies to benefit the public by reducing traffic congestion, transportation emissions, energy usage, and improving railroad operations. Eligible projects will be determined by the Secretary of Transportation. Projects eligible for funding under the "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" include increasing track capacity, acquiring rights-of-way, improving railroad-road crossings, integrating railroad systems, and repairing track structures. Funding cannot be used for operating expenses, rolling stock acquisition, debt payment, or constructing maintenance or passenger facilities. SEC. 103. INCLUSION IN STATE PLANS. Projects must be included in a long-range transportation plan, a State plan, or a transportation improvement program to be funded under this title. SEC. 104. COST SHARING. States must provide at least 20 percent of project costs funded under this title from non-Federal sources. SEC. 105. ALLOCATION OF FUNDS. The Secretary of Transportation allocates 80% of available grants to States based on a formula considering rail miles and loaded rail cars in each State. The Secretary of Transportation allocates grants to States based on rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and railroad grade crossings. 20% of the grant amount is used for discretionary grants directly by the Secretary. The Secretary of Transportation allocates grants to States based on rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and railroad grade crossings. 20% of the grant amount is used for discretionary grants directly by the Secretary for eligible projects of national significance with emphasis on projects with the greatest public benefit. SEC. 106. LABOR STANDARDS. The Secretary of Transportation ensures that laborers and mechanics on construction projects funded under this title are paid prevailing wages. SEC. 107. DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISES. SEC. 107 of the Act mandates that at least 10 percent of funds be allocated to small businesses owned by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals. Definitions for this section are based on the Transportation Equity Act. SEC. 108 defines "rail miles" as route miles and "railroad" as freight, intercity passenger, and commuter rail transportation. SEC. 201 introduces an excise tax on the sale of certain train equipment under a new subchapter E in the Internal Revenue Code. Chapter 32 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new subchapter E for Railroad Locomotives and Rolling Stock, imposing a tax under section 4191. A 5% tax is imposed on the sale of specified railroad equipment, including locomotives and rolling stock. The tax applies to manufacturers, producers, or importers. A 5% tax is imposed on the installation of parts or accessories on specified railroad equipment within 6 months of the equipment being placed in service, as per regulations prescribed by the Secretary. A 5% tax is imposed on the installation of parts or accessories on specified railroad equipment within 6 months of being placed in service. The tax applies to the price of the part or accessory and its installation, with exceptions for replacement parts. Owners of the business installing the parts are also liable for the tax. Owners of the trade or business installing parts or accessories are secondarily liable for the tax imposed on the installation. A clerical amendment is made to the table of subchapters for chapter 32 of the Code. The amendments regarding railroad locomotives and rolling stock will be effective on October 1, 2003. A new subchapter on transportation by rail is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 202. TAX ON RAIL TRANSPORTATION OF PERSONS OR PROPERTY. A new subchapter on transportation by rail is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including sections on transportation of persons and property, along with definitions and special rules. SEC. 4241 imposes a tax on taxable rail transportation of persons, with rates of 5% for commuter rail and 10% for other cases, to be paid by the person making the payment. SEC. 4242 pertains to the transportation of property. A 1% tax is imposed on amounts paid for taxable rail transportation of property within or outside the United States. The tax applies to payments made to a person engaged in the business of transporting property by rail for hire. The tax is paid by the person making the payment subject to tax, except for payments made outside the United States. The tax imposed under subsection (a) is paid by the person making the payment subject to tax. If a payment subject to tax is made outside the United States and the tax is not paid, it must be paid by the person to whom the property is delivered in the United States by the person providing the last segment of taxable transportation. The tax imposed under subsection (a) is paid by the person making the payment subject to tax. If a payment subject to tax is made outside the United States and the tax is not paid, it must be paid by the person to whom the property is delivered in the United States by the person furnishing the last segment of taxable transportation. SEC. 4243 defines special rules for tax payments on payments made outside the United States. For tax purposes, "taxable rail transportation" refers to rail travel within the US, excluding mass transit. The term "transportation" includes layover time and deadhead service movement. Special rules apply to payments made outside the US for prepaid orders. For prepaid orders made outside the US, the initial transportation provider must collect the tax. Refunds for tickets purchased without tax require deduction of the due tax amount. For tickets purchased without tax, the transportation provider must deduct any tax due under section 4241 from the refundable amount. Any remaining uncollected tax must be reported to the Secretary. If the tax is not paid at the time of transportation payment, it must be paid under regulations prescribed by the Secretary. If tax under section 4241 is not paid at the time of transportation payment, the carrier providing the initial segment of transportation in the United States must pay the tax as per regulations. A clerical amendment is made to the table of subchapters for chapter 33 of the Code. SEC. 203. NATIONAL RAIL INFRASTRUCTURE PROGRAM TRUST FUND. The amendments made by this section will be effective on October 1, 2003. Subchapter A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section establishing the National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, rolling stock, and a portion of customs duties. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, rolling stock, customs duties, fuel used in trains, and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. Amounts in the fund are available for appropriation. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund receives funding from various sources, including royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. These funds can only be used for expenditures related to the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund, funded by royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands, is designated for expenditures under the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act.
